name: Muhsen
mission: Muhsen is a nonprofit umbrella organization serving children and adults with any intellectual, mental, or physical disability. Muhsens aim is to establi...
theoryOfChange: Muhsen has a published 'Masjid Certification framework' which outlines a structured approach to achieving their mission of inclusion and accessibility for individuals with disabilities within Muslim communities. This framework provides certification guidelines for mosques to become accessible and welcoming, with different levels of certification (Silver, Gold, Platinum) based on criteria such as physical accessibility, awareness events, specialized childcare, and support groups. The organization's overall aim is to establish an inclusive and accessible environment for persons with disabilities through advocacy, education, training, and implementing programs and services. They also refer to a 'strategic plan' that guided the launch and development of their programs and services.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://muhsen.org/zakat (Source: https://muhsen.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: Muhsen holds a Charity Navigator score of 86.5/100.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and maintains a specific zakat policy.
Total revenue was $1,881,273 with a program expense ratio of 59.7%.
Muhsen operates active weekend schools and manages volunteers in CA, IL, and TX.
The organization tracks various diagnoses through its Needs Survey to tailor its advocacy.
Programs include Awareness Campaigns and Accommodation Services for individuals with disabilities.
The organization utilizes a network of registered volunteers to implement its community programs.
Muhsen uses data from needs survey respondents to establish inclusive environments.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Muhsen earns a moderate overall score due to its unique niche in domestic disability advocacy and strong financial health, though its impact score is tempered by an indirect service model.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 59.7% is lower than industry benchmarks for high-impact charities
Indirect impact model relies on community training rather than direct clinical intervention

dimension_explanations.alignment: Muhsen shows medium alignment for Muslim donors by addressing the urgent domestic need for disability inclusion within religious spaces [2][5]. Its track record is supported by active volunteer networks in California, Illinois, and Texas, though its specific focus on domestic poverty and disability may not align with donors seeking international relief [4][7].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates moderate impact through its indirect service model, focusing on community awareness and educational infrastructure rather than direct medical care [4][8]. While it maintains a Charity Navigator score of 86.5/100 and a program expense ratio of 59.7%, the lack of direct cost-per-beneficiary data limits the assessment of its overall effectiveness [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: Muhsen serves as a leading umbrella organization dedicated to establishing inclusive environments for Muslims with intellectual, mental, and physical disabilities.
strengths: High fundraising efficiency with only $0.09 spent to raise every $1
Strong liquidity position with 37.9 months of working capital
Comprehensive service model including weekend schools and needs assessment surveys
baseline_narrative.summary: Muhsen, an acronym for Muslims Understanding & Helping Special Education Needs, provides specialized programs including weekend schools and accommodation services to foster accessibility within the community [4][6]. The organization is recognized as Zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting disability advocacy [2].

strengths.detail: The organization demonstrates high fiscal discipline, spending only <cite id="1">$0.09 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions.
Muhsen maintains a strong financial cushion with <cite id="1">37.9 months of working capital</cite>, ensuring long-term operational sustainability.
The charity has earned a <cite id="1">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, the highest level of disclosure available.

strengths_deep_dive: Muhsen's operational strength lies in its ability to mobilize a large grassroots network, currently supported by <cite id="6">502 active volunteers</cite> across key regions like California, Illinois, and Texas. This volunteer base powers their <cite id="8">15 active weekend schools</cite>, which provide tailored Islamic education for students with special needs. Furthermore, the organization's <cite id="1">59.7% score in Culture & Community</cite> from Charity Navigator reflects a healthy internal environment and strong leadership alignment. Their strategic clarity is evidenced by a <cite id="1">documented Theory of Change</cite>, which focuses on transforming mosques into inclusive spaces through a multi-level certification process.
rich_narrative.summary: Muhsen, an acronym for Muslims Understanding & Helping Special Education Needs, serves as a vital umbrella organization dedicated to establishing <cite id="4">inclusive environments for Muslims with disabilities</cite>. Operating across the United States and Canada, the organization addresses a critical gap in community infrastructure by providing <cite id="5">accommodation services and national resource directories</cite>. Muhsen reported <cite id="3">$1,881,273 in total revenue</cite> for the 2022 fiscal year, demonstrating a robust <cite id="3">3-year revenue CAGR of 32.7%</cite>. The organization is distinguished by its multifaceted approach to accessibility, which includes <cite id="8">15 active weekend schools</cite> and specialized <cite id="4">Empathetic Resolution Training</cite> for community leaders. Beyond educational support, Muhsen facilitates <cite id="4">Special Needs Hajj and Umrah</cite> trips, ensuring that religious obligations are accessible to all. Their data-driven approach is anchored by a <cite id="7">needs survey tracking 2,314 diagnoses</cite>, which informs their advocacy and program development. While the organization maintains a <cite id="1">86.5/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, its model primarily focuses on <cite id="1">indirect delivery through community training</cite> and awareness rather than direct clinical intervention.
